updates.content:
If you react immediately and negatively to someone‚Äôs request for you to stop doing something that offends/upsets them, I encourage you to think more slowly. Your gut reaction, your fast efficient thinking, is built up of *your* experiences and perceptions. 

Think more slowly about your reactions and take a moment to think of the experiences of the person requesting change. 

Don‚Äôt let yourself only be defined by the experiences and perception you have until now. Grow!
updates.html:
If you react immediately and negatively to someone‚Äôs request for you to stop doing something that offends/upsets them, I encourage you to think more slowly. Your gut reaction, your fast efficient thinking, is built up of your experiences and perceptions.

Think more slowly about your reactions and take a moment to think of the experiences of the person requesting change.

Don‚Äôt let yourself only be defined by the experiences and perception you have until now. Grow!

linkData.ogTitle: Cloudflare outage caused by bad software deploy (updated)
linkData.ogDescription: Starting at 1342 UTC today we experienced a global outage across our network that resulted in visitors to Cloudflare-proxied domains being shown 502 errors (‚ÄúBad Gateway‚Äù). The cause of this outage was deployment of a single misconfigured rule within the Cloudflare Web Application Firewall (WAF)

A common theme I‚Äôve seen at #LeadDevLondon is *Listening to and Telling Stories*. Whether it‚Äôs creating a more diverse hiring process, understanding PM needs, or building a strong team, stories help us build empathy, trust, understanding, and connections. Try it today.

![](https://pietvanzoen.github.io/updates/media/2E49210F-4ADF-4C36-B9D6-D5378CA88E83.png)
updates.html: A common theme I‚Äôve seen at #LeadDevLondon is Listening to and Telling Stories. Whether it‚Äôs creating a more diverse hiring process, understanding PM needs, or building a strong team, stories help us build empathy, trust, understanding, and connections. Try it today.

updates.content: Shame is too often used as a teaching tool, but it rarely achieves those goals. More often it encourages disengagement and fear. Rather than shaming people for mistakes, create a learning opportunity and help them improve. @thisisfranklin@twitter.com #LeadDevLondon

updates.content:
Highly recommend reading this if you use npm. It‚Äôs the text from a talk given at @JSConfEU@twitter.com on Saturday by @ceejbot@twitter.com. The story of how npm came to be is pretty intriguing if you don‚Äôt know it already, but the essay leads to a pretty interesting announcement: https://github.com/ceejbot/economics-of-package-management/blob/master/essay.md

TL;DR It‚Äôs a federated package registry for JavaScript. üò± https://github.com/entropic-dev/entropic/

updates.content:
I sketched out my highlights and takeaways from @FrontendUnited@twitter.com. Lots to think about. Thanks to the organisers and amazing speakers! #FrontendUnited #sketchnotes

![Frontend united day 1 highlights. "This is for everyone". "Focus on the problem, not the solution". "Unconcious bias". "Harmony is greater than unison". "Logic is more important than code". "Information cascade". "Mystery meat menu". "How do we make the web better for everyone?"](https://pietvanzoen.github.io/updates/media/5DB31B9F-C0B6-48B6-9E4B-404EF7A37774.jpeg)
![Frontend United day 2 highlights. "A little design friction helps embed personality". "Design is applied ethics". "Stylabilla". "Variable fonts". "Should I use flexbox or grid? Yes!". "Technology is not neutral". "Disability is not a health problem. It's a mismatch of human interaction".](https://pietvanzoen.github.io/updates/media/F1BE0383-D619-4FCF-9FA1-BEE2DEA63047.jpeg)
updates.html: I sketched out my highlights and takeaways from @FrontendUnited@twitter.com. Lots to think about. Thanks to the organisers and amazing speakers! #FrontendUnited #sketchnotes

updates.content:
It‚Äôs easy to forget that part of learning to code is learning how to even get a program running, which is often more confusing/frustrating than the code. 
https://twitter.com/schmichael/status/1121823147118850048?s=21

I feel that environment knowledge is often discounted over programming knowledge. Using the command line, knowing how to install a program, knowing how to install dependencies, dealing with version control, and knowing how to debug all of the above, all of this is vital knowledge that‚Äôs hard to learn. 

So yeah. If you‚Äôre learning to code and find this hard, well, it is! Be kind to yourself. Environments are unintuitive and fickle. We‚Äôve all battled through this stuff and still do.
updates.html:
It‚Äôs easy to forget that part of learning to code is learning how to even get a program running, which is often more confusing/frustrating than the code.
https://twitter.com/schmichael/status/1121823147118850048?s=21

I feel that environment knowledge is often discounted over programming knowledge. Using the command line, knowing how to install a program, knowing how to install dependencies, dealing with version control, and knowing how to debug all of the above, all of this is vital knowledge that‚Äôs hard to learn.

So yeah. If you‚Äôre learning to code and find this hard, well, it is! Be kind to yourself. Environments are unintuitive and fickle. We‚Äôve all battled through this stuff and still do.

updates.content:
This is a big reason why I still use lodash or Ramda in a number of my projects. Clever code is rarely readable code. It feels good when you write it, but in a team working on production code readability is your no. 1 priority. 

Javascript syntax has come a long way, but sometimes a utility library is still useful to abstract common patterns that would be verbose or unreadable with today's js syntax. 

https://gomakethings.com/clever-javascript-does-not-mean-simple-or-readable/
updates.html:

Javascript syntax has come a long way, but sometimes a utility library is still useful to abstract common patterns that would be verbose or unreadable with today's js syntax.

https://gomakethings.com/clever-javascript-does-not-mean-simple-or-readable/

linkData.ogTitle: Clever JavaScript does not mean simple or readable
linkData.ogDescription:
Last week, someone tweeted:
 Woah, this is elegant JavaScript. Need to conditionally add a property to an object? Here‚Äôs a slick approach. The right-hand side is only applied if the condition is true. If the condition is falsy, the spread operator does nothing.
 They shared this code snippet from an article by Andrea Simone Costa:
const obj = { ...condition && { prop: value }, };  This is not a dig at Andrea.
linkData.twitterDescription:
Last week, someone tweeted:
 Woah, this is elegant JavaScript. Need to conditionally add a property to an object? Here‚Äôs a slick approach. The right-hand side is only applied if the condition is true. If the condition is falsy, the spread operator does nothing.
 They shared this code snippet from an article by Andrea Simone Costa:
const obj = { ...condition && { prop: value }, };  This is not a dig at Andrea.

This has definitely been my experience. I think DRY is a useful tool but taken to an extreme makes things worse. Definitely use DRY to clean up repeated values into constants. But complex abstractions tend to be wrong the first time.
